questions.text: A 27-year-old man comes to the physician because of intermittent right shoulder pain for the past 2 weeks. The pain awakens him at night and is worse when he lies on the right shoulder. He does not have any paresthesia or numbness in the right arm. He is a painter, and these episodes of pain have not allowed him to work efficiently. He appears healthy. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows painful abduction of the arm above the shoulder. There is severe pain when the elbow is flexed and the right shoulder is internally rotated. Elevation of the internally rotated and outstretched arm causes pain over the anterior lateral aspect of the shoulder. An x-ray of the shoulder shows no abnormalities. Injection of 5 mL of 1% lidocaine into the right subacromial space relieves the pain and increases the range of motion of the right arm. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In patients with suspected subacromial impingement syndrome, such as this man, an MRI of the shoulder should be performed if the etiology of the shoulder pain is unclear after initial evaluation, if symptoms fail to improve with conservative therapy, or if a soft tissue injury (e.g., rotator cuff tear) is suspected. The pain elicited in this patient is consistent with subacromial impingement syndrome. In addition, he lacks findings consistent with rotator cuff tear (e.g., loss of strength, displaced humeral head on x-ray), and he has not received prior therapy. An MRI of the shoulder is not indicated at this point.

B) INCORRECT:

Although intraarticular glucocorticoid therapy may improve symptoms in patients with chronic subacromial impingement syndrome, it is not the most appropriate next step in management for patients recently diagnosed with subacromial impingement syndrome. Other treatment options (e.g., a trial of oral analgesics) should be explored first.

C) INCORRECT:

Arthroscopic subacromial decompression is recommended for patients with chronic subacromial impingement syndrome, but it is not the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient whose symptoms started recently.

D) CORRECT:

Conservative treatment with a trial of analgesia (e.g., with NSAIDs) and physical therapy is considered the first-line therapy for patients with subacromial impingement syndrome. In patients who fail to improve with physical therapy and oral analgesics, subacromial glucocorticoid injections may provide symptomatic relief. If conservative therapy fails to improve symptoms, advanced imaging (e.g., MRI) should be obtained to rule out complications (e.g., rotator cuff tear), after which arthroscopic subacromial decompression can be considered.

For patients who present with shoulder pain, it is important to distinguish between impingement, tendinitis, and a tear of the rotator cuff. Conservative measures are appropriate in the initial management of all of these conditions, but a suspected tear in a young, active patient warrants evaluation for surgical repair.
Image Description:

The upper images shows the sectional plane and anatomy of the frontal cross-section of the shoulder. The lower images show the stages of impingement.

Stage 1, which is very painful, is characterized by irritation of the rotator cuff and bursa. Stage 2 involves fibrosis of the structures, leading to restricted function. Stage 3 involves the painful rupture of the rotator cuff, intermittent bursitis, and pseudoparalysis of the arm.

E) INCORRECT:

Thoracic outlet decompression is used to treat thoracic outlet syndrome, a condition that manifests with overhead shoulder pain. However, this condition also causes paresthesias and brachial plexus weakness, which are not seen in this case. This patient's examination findings are more consistent with a diagnosis of subacromial impingement syndrome, a condition in which thoracic outlet decompression has no role in treatment.
questions.hint: This patient's examination findings include a positive painful arc test, Hawkins-Kennedy test, Neer test, and positive lidocaine injection test, all of which raise concern for subacromial impingement syndrome. This syndrome is most common in individuals who frequently engage in overhead activities (e.g., painters).

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of persistent pain in her right shoulder. The pain is localized to the top of the shoulder and is worse with movement. She has stiffness in the right shoulder that is worse in the morning and usually lasts 20 minutes. The patient reports that she is unable to brush her hair and has stopped going to her regular tennis lessons because of the pain. She does not recall any fall or trauma. When her right arm is passively abducted in an arc, there is pain between 60 and 120 degrees of abduction. When asked to lower the right arm slowly from 90 degrees of abduction, she is unable to hold her arm up and it drops to her side. Passive range of motion is normal. Injection of 5 mL of 1% lidocaine into the right subacromial space does not relieve the pain or improve active range of motion of the right arm. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cervical radiculopathy is most often caused by spondylosis or a herniated disc in the cervical spine and may cause neck, shoulder, and/or arm pain. However, cervical radiculopathy is typically characterized by radiating pain and paresthesias and pain with passive abduction of the shoulder would not be expected.

B) CORRECT:

Subacromial impingement syndrome, rotator cuff tendinopathy, and rotator cuff tear can all manifest with pain exacerbated by overhead activity. This patient's pain with passive abduction between 60 and 120 degrees suggests impingement and/or rotator cuff disease, and the weakness seen on the drop arm test further narrows the diagnosis to a tear in the supraspinatus muscle of the rotator cuff. It is important to note that the sensitivity and specificity of these physical examination maneuvers are limited, especially with regard to rotator cuff tears; musculoskeletal ultrasound and/or MRI should be performed to confirm the diagnosis.
Image Description:

The top image shows a cross-section of the shoulder joint.

The bottom images show the progression of a degenerative rotator cuff tear. Repetitive overhead movement and/or anatomical variants of the acromion can result in inflammation of the subacromial bursa and rotator cuff tendons (left). This may progress to degeneration of the bursa and tendons (middle). As a result, the tendon fibers are less elastic and prone to tear, resulting in a rotator cuff tear (right). The supraspinatus tendon is most commonly affected.

C) INCORRECT:

Calcific tendinitis of the rotator cuff can also manifest with shoulder pain exacerbated by overhead activity, as seen in this patient. However, this patient's pain with passive movement of the arm, positive drop arm test, and negative lidocaine injection test are not consistent with calcific tendinitis.

D) INCORRECT:

Subacromial bursitis is usually due to repetitive overhead movement. It may result in subacromial impingement syndrome and can progress to adhesive capsulitis if movement is limited by pain for a prolonged period of time. Although subacromial bursitis is also characterized by pain with abduction, as seen in this patient, it would not cause weakness.

E) INCORRECT:

Polymyalgia rheumatica (PMR) is most common in women > 50 years old and can manifest with shoulder pain and morning stiffness. However, pain from PMR is usually bilateral, diffuse, and accompanied by neck pain and/or pelvic girdle pain. Although this patient complains of morning stiffness, PMR is characterized by prolonged morning stiffness (> 45 minutes). Additionally, this patient's weakness on examination is not consistent with PMR.

F) INCORRECT:

Biceps tendinitis is usually due to repetitive lifting or pulling activities. It typically manifests with anterior shoulder pain that radiates down the anterior upper arm. The pain with passive abduction and weakness seen in this patient is not consistent with biceps tendinitis.

G) INCORRECT:

Rotator cuff tendinitis is common in individuals who engage in repetitive overhead activities and may also manifest with shoulder pain and weakness exacerbated by activity. The pain associated with rotator cuff tendinitis should resolve with subacromial lidocaine injection. This patient's continued pain and limited range of motion suggest another diagnosis.

H) INCORRECT:

Adhesive capsulitis (frozen shoulder) typically manifests with shoulder pain and limited active range of motion which typically does not improve significantly with a lidocaine injection test. However, passive range of motion is typically restricted in patients with frozen shoulders, making this diagnosis unlikely.
questions.hint: The patient's inability to hold up her arm at 90 degrees of abduction indicates a positive drop arm test.

questions.text: A 33-year-old man on active duty in the US Army comes to the clinic because of a 1-day history of right shoulder pain. The pain developed acutely during a lifting exercise, after which he was unable to lift his arm. He could not sleep last night because of the pain. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows mild swelling over the right shoulder. The right deltoid and distal clavicular region are tender to palpation. Active abduction and external rotation of the right shoulder are severely limited by pain. Passive external rotation is painful. An x-ray of the right shoulder is shown. An MRI of the right shoulder shows complete discontinuity of the supraspinatus tendon and mild effusion in the subacromial space. The shoulder is immobilized with a sling and analgesic therapy is initiated. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Closed reduction of the shoulder is used in the management of shoulder dislocation, which can manifest with acute pain and an inability to move the shoulder. However, in shoulder dislocation, an empty glenoid fossa or displacement of the humeral head are often palpable, and imaging studies show a displacement of the humeral head from the glenoid fossa.
Image Description:

X-ray right shoulder (AP view (left); lateral (scapular) Y-view (right))

There is anterior and inferior displacement of the humeral head from the glenoid fossa. Hill-Sachs lesion can be seen in AP view.

B) INCORRECT:

Arthrocentesis of the shoulder is indicated when synovial fluid analysis is required to rule out pathologies such as joint infection (septic arthritis) or crystal-induced arthropathy (e.g., gout, pseudogout), both of which manifest with shoulder pain, swelling, and tenderness on palpation. However, this patient has no fever (making infection less likely) and no imaging findings consistent with pseudogout (e.g., degenerative changes). Furthermore, the shoulder is not typically affected by gout. This patient most likely has a rotator cuff tear, for which arthrocentesis is not indicated.

C) CORRECT:

Surgical repair is indicated in acute, full-thickness traumatic rotator cuff tears, especially in physically active patients; a delay in surgical repair can lead to significant muscle atrophy and tendon retraction and can worsen surgical outcomes. In older patients or those with a high surgical risk, conservative management (e.g., physical therapy, corticosteroid injections, topical analgesia) is recommended over surgical repair; in these patients, surgery may be considered if conservative measures fail.
Image Description:

MRI right shoulder (fluid sensitive fat-suppressed sequence; coronal plane)

A tear of the hypointense supraspinatus tendon (white arrow) has resulted in tendon retraction proximally. Fluid (red arrow) inferior to the acromion (green overlay) in the subacromial-subdeltoid space appears hyperintense and communicates with joint effusion along the rest of the humeral head.

These are MRI features of a full-thickness tear of the supraspinatus tendon

a: deltoid muscle; b: clavicle; c: trapezius muscle; d: supraspinatus muscle; e: subscapularis muscle

D) INCORRECT:

A subacromial corticosteroid injection may be considered for chronic shoulder pain (due to, e.g., rotator cuff tendinopathy) if other measures have not provided adequate relief. In a young, physically active patient with an acute, full-thickness rotator cuff tear, another step in management is indicated.

E) INCORRECT:

Reassurance is indicated in patients with simple muscle strains. This patient with a suspected traumatic rotator cuff tear on examination requires further management to reduce the risk of significant muscle atrophy and tendon retraction.
questions.hint: Limited abduction and external rotation in addition to complete discontinuity of the supraspinatus tendon on MRI in a patient with acute shoulder pain indicates an acute, full-thickness rotator cuff tear, which is a common injury among athletes.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of worsening dull left shoulder pain. The pain has caused her to wake up most nights. She regularly plays volleyball with her daughter but she says that her shoulder feels very stiff now and changing clothes or fastening her bra has become increasingly difficult over the past 6 months. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus treated with metformin. Two years ago, she had a type 1 acromioclavicular joint injury treated with a sling. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a markedly decreased active and passive range of motion in her left shoulder due to pain; muscle strength is 4/5 in her left shoulder. Neurologic examination shows no other focal findings. X-rays of the left shoulder show no abnormalities. In addition to prescribing analgesics, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Recommend shoulder immobilization with a sling

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The initial treatment of adhesive capsulitis (frozen shoulder) should consist of conservative measures such as movement restriction (e.g., overhead movements), NSAIDs, and physical therapy for shoulder range-of-motion exercises. Physical therapy should aim to strengthen and gently stretch the shoulder while avoiding aggressive exercises that would aggravate the capsular synovitis and cause undue discomfort. Patients with previous shoulder injuries and/or surgeries, diabetes mellitus, and other systemic diseases (e.g., stroke, thyroid, autoimmune) are at increased risk of developing adhesive capsulitis.
Image Description:

Frontal cross-section of the shoulder and the three stages of frozen shoulder

Stage 1 (freezing stage): minimal synovitis with pain and limitation of motion
Stage 2 (frozen stage): proliferative synovitis with contraction of the capsule and adhesion of the axillary recess
Stage 3 (thawing stage): contracted capsule following the end of inflammation

B) INCORRECT:

A short course of oral corticosteroids can help to improve mobility and reduce pain in patients with adhesive capsulitis. However, this benefit does not extend beyond a few weeks and is typically not recommended due to the systemic side effects of corticosteroids (e.g., hypertension, hyperglycemia, weight gain, peptic ulcers, myopathy, psychosis). Instead, conservative measures should be trialed first. In patients who do not respond to conservative measures, intraarticular glucocorticoid injections, which have more localized effects, can be considered instead of oral steroids.

C) INCORRECT:

Surgical treatment, such as the arthroscopic release of the glenohumeral joint capsule, can be used to treat adhesive capsulitis. However, surgical interventions should be reserved for patients who have not responded to conservative measures (e.g., physical therapy, NSAIDs, shoulder injections). Conservative measures should be exhausted in this patient before surgery is considered.

D) INCORRECT:

Immobilization of the shoulder should be considered after an injury to the acromioclavicular joint, which typically occurs after trauma and can manifest with swelling and/or bruising. This patient's normal x-ray and symptoms indicate adhesive capsulitis, which can worsen with immobilization.

E) INCORRECT:

MRI of the shoulder can be used to assess soft tissue injuries (e.g., rotator cuff tendons, bursa, shoulder ligaments) and can show thickening of the glenohumeral capsule in patients with adhesive capsulitis. However, adhesive capsulitis is typically diagnosed based on patient history and physical examination; MRI is not recommended unless the patient has evidence of another pathology. This patient's adhesive capsulitis can be diagnosed clinically and treatment should be started.
questions.hint: A history of a shoulder injury in a patient with progressive unilateral shoulder pain and stiffness who is otherwise physically active suggests adhesive capsulitis (frozen shoulder).

questions.text: An 18-year-old man presents to the office because of a 2-month history of gradually increasing right shoulder pain. He is an avid tennis player and mentions that the pain is most noticeable while serving or hitting overhead shots. He denies any history of trauma but admits that he recently increased the intensity of his training. The patient mentions that he wants to receive osteopathic manipulative treatment because it was recommended by his tennis partner. On physical examination, there is tenderness to palpation on the anterolateral aspect of the right shoulder. Passive range of motion is full. Active abduction of the right shoulder elicits pain between 60 and 120 degrees. Muscle strength of both upper extremities is preserved. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Thoracic outlet syndrome (TOS) is caused by compression of the subclavian vessels and lower trunk of the brachial plexus, mainly in the scalene triangle. Causes include repetitive motion of the abducted and externally rotated shoulder (e.g., tennis, baseball, swimming). Although pain usually worsens during or after overhead activity, it is typically located in the neck and arm and is accompanied by paresthesia along the ulnar nerve distribution. Adson test and Wright test would be positive while a painful arc test would be negative.

B) INCORRECT:

An infraspinatus tear is most commonly caused by chronic degeneration and is often seen in individuals who perform repetitive overhead movements. Although this condition causes shoulder pain and does not affect passive range of motion, it would manifest with loss of muscle strength and restricted active range of motion. An infraspinatus test would be positive while a painful arc test would be negative.

C) INCORRECT:

Biceps tendinopathy can result from isolated tendinitis due to overload or overuse injury (common in athletes). Although shoulder pain is gradual in onset and worsens with overhead activities, it is mainly located in the anterior aspect of the shoulder and at the bicipital groove. Tests that are specific to the biceps (e.g., Yergason test, Speed test) would be positive while painful arc test would be negative.

D) CORRECT:

Rotator cuff tendinopathy is characterized by inflammatory and/or degenerative changes to one or more of the rotator cuff tendons, most commonly the supraspinatus tendon. This condition is usually caused by an acute injury or chronic degeneration from overuse (e.g., playing tennis). Rotator cuff tendinopathy manifests with shoulder pain, subacromial tenderness, and pain on movement (especially between 60 and 120, i.e., painful arc), that worsens with overhead activities (e.g., serving or hitting overhead shots) and can radiate to the deltoid area. Unlike in a rotator cuff rupture, muscle strength is usually preserved. Diagnosis is typically clinical and based on provocation testing (e.g., painful arc test, Jobe test, belly press test, and infraspinatus test). MRI or ultrasound is used for definitive diagnosis. Conservative therapy is indicated for shoulder soft tissue lesions.

E) INCORRECT:

Frozen shoulder is a contracture of the shoulder joint due to inflammation and fibrosis of the joint capsule. Although this condition causes shoulder pain, it most commonly affects the nondominant side. This condition can be primary (e.g., associated with diabetes mellitus, thyroid disorders) or secondary (i.e., associated with a previous shoulder injury). Other clinical features include stiffness that interferes with activities of daily life and severe restriction of active and passive range of motion of the glenohumeral joint.
questions.hint: This patient would have a positive Jobe test, also known as an empty can test. In this test, the patient outstretches and internally rotates their arm (mimicking the emptying of a can). If pain is elicited or the patient cannot maintain the position, the test is positive.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old woman presents to the office with a 3-week history of worsening dull pain in her left shoulder. The pain has caused her to wake up most nights. She used to play volleyball regularly with her daughter, but over the past 6 months, her shoulder has felt very stiff, and changing clothes or fastening her bra has become increasingly difficult. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus treated with metformin. Two years ago, she had a type 1 acromioclavicular joint injury treated with a sling. Physical examination reveals:


Decreased active and passive range of motion of the left shoulder due to pain
4/5 muscle strength of the left shoulder
Normal neurologic findings
No bony deformities of the left shoulder

X-rays of the left shoulder show no abnormalities. In addition to prescribing analgesics, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Recommend shoulder immobilization with a sling

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

MRI of the shoulder can be used to assess soft tissue injuries (e.g., rotator cuff tendons, bursa, shoulder ligaments) and can show thickening of the glenohumeral capsule in patients with adhesive capsulitis. However, adhesive capsulitis is typically diagnosed based on patient history and physical examination; MRI is not recommended unless the patient has evidence of another pathology. This patient's adhesive capsulitis can be diagnosed clinically and treatment should be started.

B) INCORRECT:

A short course of oral corticosteroids can help to improve mobility and reduce pain in patients with adhesive capsulitis. However, this benefit does not extend beyond a few weeks and is typically not recommended due to the systemic side effects of corticosteroids (e.g., hypertension, hyperglycemia, weight gain, peptic ulcers, myopathy, psychosis). Instead, conservative measures should be trialed first. In patients who do not respond to conservative measures, intraarticular glucocorticoid injections, which have more localized effects, can be considered instead of oral steroids.

C) INCORRECT:

Immobilization of the shoulder should be considered after an injury to the acromioclavicular joint, which typically occurs after trauma and can manifest with swelling and/or bruising. This patient's normal x-ray and symptoms indicate adhesive capsulitis, which can worsen with immobilization.

D) INCORRECT:

Surgical treatment, such as the arthroscopic release of the glenohumeral joint capsule, can be used to treat adhesive capsulitis. However, surgical interventions should be reserved for patients who have not responded to conservative measures (e.g., physical therapy, NSAIDs, shoulder injections). Conservative measures should be exhausted in this patient before surgery is considered.

E) CORRECT:

Adhesive capsulitis (frozen shoulder) is initially managed conservatively with early mobilization of the joint, NSAIDs, and shoulder range-of-motion exercises, like the Spencer technique. The Spencer technique is an osteopathic articulatory technique that guides the affected shoulder through seven stages of movement using passive range of motion to gently stretch the shoulder. Patients should avoid aggressive exercise that could aggravate the capsular synovitis and cause discomfort. Individuals with previous shoulder injuries and/or surgeries, diabetes mellitus, stroke, and other systemic diseases (e.g., thyroid, autoimmune) are at increased risk of developing adhesive capsulitis.

Because the Spencer technique improves glenohumeral joint mobility, it can be useful in other conditions involving shoulder pain and stiffness, such as fibrosis following a rotator cuff injury or shoulder restriction following immobilization due to a humerus fracture.
Image Description:

Frontal cross-section of the shoulder and the three stages of frozen shoulder

Stage 1 (freezing stage): minimal synovitis with pain and limitation of motion
Stage 2 (frozen stage): proliferative synovitis with contraction of the capsule and adhesion of the axillary recess
Stage 3 (thawing stage): contracted capsule following the end of inflammation
questions.hint: A history of a shoulder injury in a patient with progressive unilateral shoulder pain and stiffness who is otherwise physically active suggests adhesive capsulitis (frozen shoulder).

questions.text:
A 42-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes has right shoulder pain that started acutely 2 days ago. She denies any trauma, repetitive shoulder motion, rash, fevers, chills, skin breakdown, dysuria, or new sexual partners.
On examination, she is afebrile. Her right shoulder is warm and erythematous; the erythema extends from the greater tuberosity of the humerus to the subacromial bursa. Her range of motion is severely limited by pain but improved modestly when she took a nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drug.
Plain radiographs of the right shoulder reveal small and scattered homogeneous, amorphous densities in the soft tissues near the greater tuberosity of the humerus.
Which one of the following diagnoses is the most likely explanation for this patients presentation?

choices.text: Gonococcal arthritis of the glenohumeral joint
Acute calcium pyrophosphate crystal arthritis (pseudogout) of the glenohumeral joint
Gouty arthritis of the glenohumeral joint
Calcific tendinitis of the supraspinatus tendon

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Gonococcal arthritis is not typically accompanied by calcification in the regional soft tissue.

B) INCORRECT:

Radiographs of patients with acute calcium pyrophosphate crystal arthritis (pseudogout) would typically show chondrocalcinosis, i.e., calcification of cartilage in the affected joints.

C) INCORRECT:

Radiographs of patients with gout would typically show rat-bite erosions, i.e., lytic bone lesions with overhanging edges (spiky periosteal oppositions).

D) CORRECT:

Acute calcific tendinitis (also known as calcific periarthritis) is an acute inflammatory process caused by basic calcium phosphate crystals (typically calcium hydroxyapatite) deposited along tendons and other periarticular soft tissues. The pain and functional limitations of this condition can mimic an inflammatory monoarthritis, but it is a periarticular process. The shoulder is most commonly affected, but almost any joint can be involved, including the neck, fingers, wrists, elbows, and toes. Diabetes mellitus and chronic kidney disease are risk factors.

Physical examination may show warmth, swelling, and erythema but cannot differentiate calcific tendinitis from causes of an acute-onset monoarthritis, such as gout, acute calcium pyrophosphate crystal arthritis (pseudogout), or infectious arthritis. In any of these conditions, including calcific tendinitis, laboratory findings may include leukocytosis and elevations in acute-phase reactants, such as C-reactive protein and erythrocyte sedimentation rate; these findings are nonspecific.

The key to diagnosing acute calcific tendinitis is plain radiography. Radiographs will typically show calcifications in the periarticular soft tissues of the affected area, with no chondrocalcinosis (which would be suggestive of acute calcium pyrophosphate crystal arthritis) and no erosions with overhanging edges (which would be suggestive of gout). The presence of radiographic calcifications and the absence of systemic symptoms and risk factors for infectious arthritis can help to differentiate calcific tendinitis from infectious etiologies. Calcifications can also be found as an incidental finding in asymptomatic patients without features of acute tendinitis.

Calcific tendinitis is treated conservatively with rest and nonsteroidal antiinflammatory agents. Glucocorticoid injection into an adjoining bursa, tendon sheath, or joint can provide rapid relief. Ultrasound-guided lavage of the calcific material can be helpful in patients with recurrent or refractory episodes.

Key learning point: In a symptomatic patient, calcific tendinitis of the rotator cuff can be distinguished radiographically from causes of inflammatory arthritis by plain film radiographs showing the presence of calcifications in the soft tissues surrounding the affected tendon.
Image Description:

X-ray right shoulder (external rotation view)

Calcific densities (green overlay) are seen in the subacromial space adjacent to the greater tuberosity of the humerus.

The appearance is consistent with basic calcium phosphate calcific-associated periarthritis (calcific tendinitis or calcific tendinopathy) in the region of the tendon of the supraspinatus muscle.

E) INCORRECT:

In contrast to acute calcific tendinitis, rotator-cuff tears and tendinitis due to trauma or overuse cause a loss of range of motion without warmth and erythema on examination.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old woman with type 1 diabetes mellitus reports a 3-month history of worsening right-shoulder pain that makes it difficult for her to reach overhead and backward. She has no history of recent injury.
Her active and passive ranges of motion are quite limited on abduction, external rotation, and internal rotation. She has a mildly positive impingement sign with normal strength.
An anterior shoulder radiograph is obtained (figure).
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Glenohumeral osteoarthritis can limit internal rotation of the shoulder but is typically associated with radiographic abnormalities.

B) INCORRECT:

Glenohumeral dislocation can limit internal rotation of the shoulder but is typically associated with radiographic abnormalities.

C) INCORRECT:

Supraspinatus tears are associated with limited abduction but not limited internal rotation; they are also associated with weakness with active abduction, particularly when the arm is hanging in the neutral position.

D) INCORRECT:

Bicipital tendinosis is not usually associated with substantially limited range of motion.

E) CORRECT:

Adhesive capsulitis typically develops subacutely. It manifests as pain and limited range of motion on abduction, internal rotation, and external rotation. Without antecedent trauma, adhesive capsulitis is much more common in patients with diabetes mellitus than in nondiabetic patients. Therapeutic interventions for adhesive capsulitis include physical therapy, intra-articular glucocorticoid injection, and (for refractory cases) arthroscopic surgical release and/or manipulation under anesthesia.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in a patient with limited passive and active range of motion in abduction, internal rotation, and external rotation of the shoulder is adhesive capsulitis.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old woman with a history of hypertension, type 2 diabetes, and chronic renal insufficiency (creatinine level, 2.1 mg/dL; reference range, 0.61.1) reports 2 weeks of pain in her right shoulder. The pain worsens when she tries to comb her hair or reach into a cabinet; it wakes her from sleep when she rolls onto her right side; and it occasionally radiates down her right arm. She denies a history of trauma, neck pain, left shoulder pain, or paresthesias in her fingers.
No muscle atrophy is evident on physical examination. The patient has mildly limited internal rotation but intact external rotation of her right shoulder. There is no crepitus. A Jobes (i.e., empty can) test  passive abduction of the shoulder to 90 degrees, flexed to 30 degrees with the thumb pointed down, and then lifting of the arm against resistance  produces significant pain. A drop-arm test is negative; that is, she can gradually lower her arm to her side after it has been fully abducted passively. Her muscle strength is symmetric and intact.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate in this case?

choices.text: Immobilize the shoulder with a sling

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

If symptoms persist after a course of physical therapy, a glucocorticoid injection (e.g., methylprednisolone or triamcinolone) would be indicated.

B) CORRECT:

This patient has clinical signs of rotator-cuff tendinitis, which is often accompanied by subacromial bursitis. Pain tends to be exacerbated by raising the arm over the head or lying on the affected side during sleep. Reproduction of pain by resisted use of the supraspinatus muscle via a Jobe (i.e., empty can) test, among others, is common. The initial treatment when symptoms are of recent onset is exercise-based physical therapy to avoid development of adhesive capsulitis caused by immobilization.

Key learning point: The most appropriate initial treatment for recent-onset rotator cuff tendinitis, without evidence of a complete tendon tear, is a physical therapy program.

C) INCORRECT:

The patients intact strength and ability to gradually lower her arm from a fully abducted position (negative drop-arm test) suggest that she is unlikely to have a full-thickness rotator-cuff tear; therefore, she is unlikely to require surgical repair.

D) INCORRECT:

Pain medication, such as a nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drug, is indicated for rotator-cuff tendinitis; however, in a patient with chronic renal insufficiency, ibuprofen should be avoided.

E) INCORRECT:

Immobilization of a shoulder affected by rotator-cuff tendinitis or other sources of chronic shoulder pain can lead to adhesive capsulitis.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old man who is right-hand dominant reports having diffuse right shoulder pain for the past 6 months. The pain began after he played shortstop for four games during a weekend softball tournament. He landed on his right shoulder while diving into second base during one of the games. He is not sure, but he feels as though the shoulder might have slid out of and then back into place. He reports pain with any overhead movement and feels as though his shoulder is weaker.
He has pain over the lateral deltoid on palpation and with abduction of the shoulder to 90 degrees.
What additional physical examination finding would most support the diagnosis of a rotator-cuff tear in this patient?

choices.text: Apprehensiveness of the patient while supine with the shoulder abducted 90 degrees in full external rotation while the examiner applies downward pressure

Reproduction of patients pain against resistance when the shoulder is flexed to 90 degrees and the arm is adducted across midline with the thumb down, and relief of the pain when the thumb is pointed up
Marked weakness with the shoulder abducted to 90 degrees in the scapular plane with the thumb pointed down
Tenderness to palpation over the acromioclavicular joint
Normal strength with the shoulder elevated to 90 degrees in the scapular plane with the thumb pointed up

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The apprehension test is used to test for shoulder instability. The shoulder is abducted 90 degrees in full external rotation. The examiner applies pressure to the proximal humerus from behind the patient. This test is positive if the patient becomes apprehensive and resists further pressure on the shoulder.

B) INCORRECT:

An OBrien test, which evaluates for labral pathology, is performed with the patient flexing the shoulder to 90 degrees and adducting the arm across the midline with the thumb down. Reproduction of pain against resistance and relief of pain when the thumb is pointed up are suggestive of a labral tear.

C) CORRECT:

Diagnosis of a rotator-cuff tear involves combining key elements of the patients history and physical examination. No one test confirms this pathology. Full-thickness rotator-cuff tears are more likely after trauma. Patients often describe pain and limitations with active range of motion but are pain-free with passive range of motion.

On examination, some of the most sensitive and specific findings of full-thickness rotator-cuff tears are weakness of rotator-cuff muscles, limited and painful active range of motion, full and pain-free passive range of motion, and a painful arc (pain elicited from approximately 50 to 120 degrees of active abduction). Specific physical examination maneuvers that can help identify rotator-cuff muscle weakness include weakness with external rotation and positive findings on empty-can and full-can tests. The latter two tests are performed by providing resistance when the patients shoulder is abducted to 90 degrees in the scapular plane with the thumb pointed down (empty-can test) or up (full-can test); the presence of pain or weakness is a positive test, whereas the absence of weakness would make rotator-cuff pathology less likely. The full-can test can be less painful and thus more tolerable for the patient but will still test for supraspinatus weakness.

Key learning point: The physical examination findings that most support the diagnosis of a full-thickness tear of the rotator cuff are a painful arc and weakness of the rotator cuff with the shoulder abducted to 90 degrees in the scapular plane with the thumb pointed down (empty-can test).

D) INCORRECT:

Palpation plays an important role in diagnosis of shoulder pathology. Tenderness over the acromioclavicular (AC) joint is indicative of AC joint arthrosis, whereas tenderness over the biceps groove may be more indicative of biceps tendon tearing or tendonitis.

E) INCORRECT:

Specific physical examination maneuvers that can help identify rotator-cuff muscle weakness include weakness with external rotation and positive findings on empty-can and full-can tests. The latter two tests are performed by providing resistance when the patients shoulder is abducted to 90 degrees in the scapular plane with the thumb pointed down (empty-can test) or up (full-can test); the presence of pain or weakness is a positive test, whereas the absence of weakness would make rotator-cuff pathology less likely.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old woman with a history of diabetes and hypertension reports pain and stiffness in the anterior and lateral aspects of her right shoulder. Her symptoms have progressed for the past 2 weeks. She denies any precipitating event or trauma.
Her vital signs are within normal limits. Her right shoulder has a normal appearance, and there is no tenderness to palpation. Her active and passive range of motion is limited, most notably with external rotation where her active and passive motion are equal. Her strength is intact within her range of motion. Neer, Hawkins, Speed, Spurling, and OBrien tests are all normal. Her distal neurovascular status is intact.
A radiograph of the right shoulder is obtained (figure).
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cervical radiculopathy manifests with weakness in the distribution of the affected nerve root. Patients may present with neck pain that radiates to the shoulder, but isolated shoulder pain is uncommon. Active range of motion may be affected depending on the nerve root level involved, but passive range of motion is intact. A Spurling test is often positive in these patients. Initial treatment is physical therapy, followed by referral to a spine surgeon if the problem persists.

B) INCORRECT:

Shoulder impingement syndrome is more common in patients who perform repetitive overhead activity that leads to inflammation of subacromial structures related to the repetitive compression. Involved structures include the subacromial bursa and rotator-cuff tendons that traverse the subacromial space. Physical examination maneuvers that support this diagnosis include positive Neer and Hawkins tests. Patients with shoulder impingement syndrome typically respond well to physical therapy, subacromial glucocorticoid injection, or both.

C) CORRECT:

Idiopathic adhesive capsulitis is most common in middle-aged white women with a history of diabetes. Affected patients usually present with vague, subacute, atraumatic shoulder pain associated with limited range of motion that is most notable in external rotation. Secondary adhesive capsulitis is also common in this age group and differs from primary or idiopathic adhesive capsulitis in that it is occurs in the weeks to months after an acute shoulder injury.

Physical therapy is the best initial treatment option. If this approach is not successful, a trial of glenohumeral glucocorticoid injection, followed by more physical therapy, is the next step. In drug-refractory cases, referral to an orthopedic surgeon for examination under anesthesia and operative release may be necessary. Resolution of symptoms can take months to more than a year from initial onset.

Key learning point: Right shoulder pain associated with limited external rotation is typical for a diagnosis of adhesive capsulitis.

D) INCORRECT:

A rotator-cuff tear is usually related to a traumatic event. Affected patients typically have some limitation in active range of motion along with deficits in rotator-cuff strength. In an acute setting, referral to an orthopedic surgeon for possible operative repair is warranted.

E) INCORRECT:

Glenohumeral arthritis usually manifests as chronic shoulder pain associated with a painful range of motion but normal rotator-cuff strength. Shoulder radiographs show degenerative change, most notably on the Grashey view. Initial treatment includes glucocorticoid injection and physical therapy. Advanced cases may merit evaluation by an orthopedic surgeon for possible shoulder replacement.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old avid weightlifter who is right-hand-dominant has been experiencing right anterior shoulder pain after his workouts for 2 months. The pain recurs predictably with shoulder activity, and lifting weight overhead is particularly painful. He has no prior injuries to this shoulder. He also denies any neck pain, paresthesias, popping, or clicking. No visible shoulder deformity is evident, and the anterior shoulder is minimally tender to palpation.
The shoulder has full active range of motion but causes pain upon abduction and forward-flexing above 90 degrees. The rotator cuff muscles have full strength. The pain is reproduced when passively internally rotating and forward-flexing the shoulder (Neer test), as well as passively flexing the elbow and shoulder to 90 degrees and then internally rotating the shoulder (Hawkins test). Resisted shoulder forward flexion with thumb up (full can) and thumb down (empty can) testing at 30 degrees of adduction demonstrates 5/5 strength. With the arm at 90 degrees of forward flexion and the elbow extended, internal rotation of the shoulder does not produce pain (O'Brien test).
There is no pain when the shoulder is flexed to 90 degrees and adducted across the midline with the thumb down against resistance or in the same position with the thumb pointed up. Nor is there pain with the shoulder flexed to 90 degrees and supinated against resistance. The patient has no apprehension while supine with the shoulder abducted 90 degrees in full external rotation with downward pressure.
The neurovasculature is intact.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Biceps tendinopathy may sometimes overlap with subacromial impingement syndrome. However, it is unlikely in this case, as the patient has no pain upon testing of his proximal biceps tendon while flexing and supinating his shoulder to 90 degrees against resistance.

B) CORRECT:

Subacromial impingement, a common cause of shoulder pain often resulting from overuse, may have anatomical or functional causes. Affected patients typically have a painful range of motion, especially with overhead movements.

Neer and Hawkins tests are often positive in patients with subacromial impingement syndrome. A Neer test involves passively internally rotating and forward-flexing the shoulder to reproduce the pain. A Hawkins test involves flexing the elbow and shoulder to 90 degrees and then internally rotating the shoulder. The tests are positive if they reproduce the patient's pain.

The initial therapy for subacromial impingement is conservative: antiinflammatory drugs, avoidance of painful activities, icing, and a shoulder strengthening and conditioning program.

Key learning point: Subacromial impingement is characterized by positive impingement signs and normal strength of the rotator-cuff muscles.

C) INCORRECT:

Myofascial pain syndrome is a chronic pain disorder characterized by multiple painful trigger points. Palpation of trigger points causes focal and referred pain as well as muscle spasm.

D) INCORRECT:

A labral tear is unlikely given that the patient has anterior shoulder pain, positive impingement signs, and a negative OBrien test.

E) INCORRECT:

Other than patient history, one key way to distinguish subacromial impingement syndrome from a full-thickness rotator-cuff tear is to detect normal strength of the rotator-cuff muscles within the pain-free range of motion. A full-thickness rotator-cuff tear is unlikely in this patient given the absence of trauma, normal strength of the rotator-cuff muscles, and positive impingement signs.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman comes to the office because of a 2-month history of persistent pain in her right shoulder. The pain is localized to the top of the shoulder and is worse with movement. The patient reports that she is unable to brush her hair and has stopped going to her regular tennis lessons because of the pain. When her right arm is passively abducted in an arc, there is pain between 60 and 120 degrees of abduction. When asked to lower the right arm slowly from 90 degrees of abduction, she is unable to hold her arm up and it drops to her side. Passive range of motion is normal. Injection of 5 mL of 1% lidocaine into the right subacromial space does not relieve the pain or improve active range of motion of the right arm. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Subacromial impingement syndrome, rotator cuff tendinopathy, and rotator cuff tear can all manifest with pain exacerbated by overhead activity. This patient's pain with passive abduction between 60 and 120 degrees suggests impingement and/or rotator cuff disease, and the weakness seen on the drop arm test further narrows the diagnosis to a tear in the supraspinatus muscle of the rotator cuff. It is important to note that the sensitivity and specificity of these physical examination maneuvers are limited, especially with regard to rotator cuff tears; musculoskeletal ultrasound and/or MRI should be performed to confirm the diagnosis.

Key learning point: A rotator cuff tear typically presents with shoulder pain, weakness, and a positive drop arm test, often confirmed by imaging such as MRI or ultrasound.
Image Description:

The top image shows a cross-section of the shoulder joint.

The bottom images show the progression of a degenerative rotator cuff tear. Repetitive overhead movement and/or anatomical variants of the acromion can result in inflammation of the subacromial bursa and rotator cuff tendons (left). This may progress to degeneration of the bursa and tendons (middle). As a result, the tendon fibers are less elastic and prone to tear, resulting in a rotator cuff tear (right). The supraspinatus tendon is most commonly affected.

B) INCORRECT:

Calcific tendinitis of the rotator cuff can also manifest with shoulder pain exacerbated by overhead activity, as seen in this patient. However, this patient's pain with passive movement of the arm, positive drop arm test, and negative lidocaine injection test are not consistent with calcific tendinitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Subacromial bursitis is usually due to repetitive overhead movement. It may result in subacromial impingement syndrome and can progress to adhesive capsulitis if movement is limited by pain for a prolonged period of time. Although subacromial bursitis is also characterized by pain with abduction, as seen in this patient, it would not cause weakness.

D) INCORRECT:

Rotator cuff tendinitis is common in individuals who engage in repetitive overhead activities and may also manifest with shoulder pain and weakness exacerbated by activity. The pain associated with rotator cuff tendinitis should resolve with subacromial lidocaine injection. This patient's continued pain and limited range of motion suggest another diagnosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Adhesive capsulitis (frozen shoulder) typically manifests with shoulder pain and limited active range of motion which typically does not improve significantly with a lidocaine injection test. However, passive range of motion is typically restricted in patients with frozen shoulders, making this diagnosis unlikely.
questions.hint: The patient's inability to hold up her arm at 90 degrees of abduction indicates a positive drop arm test.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents with a 3-week history of worsening dull left shoulder pain. The pain has caused her to wake up most nights. She says that her shoulder feels very stiff now and changing clothes or fastening her bra has become increasingly difficult over the past 6 months. Two years ago, she had a type 1 acromioclavicular joint injury treated with a sling. Physical examination shows a markedly decreased active and passive range of motion in her left shoulder due to pain; muscle strength is 4/5 in her left shoulder. Neurologic examination shows no other focal findings. X-rays of the left shoulder show no abnormalities. In addition to prescribing analgesics, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Recommend shoulder immobilization with a sling

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The initial treatment of adhesive capsulitis (frozen shoulder) should consist of conservative measures such as movement restriction (e.g., overhead movements), NSAIDs, and physical therapy for shoulder range-of-motion exercises. Physical therapy should aim to strengthen and gently stretch the shoulder while avoiding aggressive exercises that would aggravate the capsular synovitis and cause undue discomfort. Patients with previous shoulder injuries and/or surgeries, diabetes mellitus, and other systemic diseases (e.g., stroke, thyroid, autoimmune) are at increased risk of developing adhesive capsulitis.
Image Description:

Frontal cross-section of the shoulder and the three stages of frozen shoulder

Stage 1 (freezing stage): minimal synovitis with pain and limitation of motion
Stage 2 (frozen stage): proliferative synovitis with contraction of the capsule and adhesion of the axillary recess
Stage 3 (thawing stage): contracted capsule following the end of inflammation

B) INCORRECT:

A short course of oral corticosteroids can help to improve mobility and reduce pain in patients with adhesive capsulitis. However, this benefit does not extend beyond a few weeks and is typically not recommended due to the systemic side effects of corticosteroids (e.g., hypertension, hyperglycemia, weight gain, peptic ulcers, myopathy, psychosis). Instead, conservative measures should be trialed first. In patients who do not respond to conservative measures, intraarticular glucocorticoid injections, which have more localized effects, can be considered instead of oral steroids.

C) INCORRECT:

Surgical treatment, such as the arthroscopic release of the glenohumeral joint capsule, can be used to treat adhesive capsulitis. However, surgical interventions should be reserved for patients who have not responded to conservative measures (e.g., physical therapy, NSAIDs, shoulder injections). Conservative measures should be exhausted in this patient before surgery is considered.

D) INCORRECT:

Immobilization of the shoulder should be considered after an injury to the acromioclavicular joint, which typically occurs after trauma and can manifest with swelling and/or bruising. This patient's normal x-ray and symptoms indicate adhesive capsulitis, which can worsen with immobilization.

E) INCORRECT:

MRI of the shoulder can be used to assess soft tissue injuries (e.g., rotator cuff tendons, bursa, shoulder ligaments) and can show thickening of the glenohumeral capsule in patients with adhesive capsulitis. However, adhesive capsulitis is typically diagnosed based on patient history and physical examination; MRI is not recommended unless the patient has evidence of another pathology. This patient's adhesive capsulitis can be diagnosed clinically and treatment should be started.
questions.hint: A history of a shoulder injury in a patient with progressive unilateral shoulder pain and stiffness who is otherwise physically active suggests adhesive capsulitis (frozen shoulder).

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman with type 1 diabetes mellitus reports a 3-month history of worsening right-shoulder pain that makes it difficult for her to reach overhead and backward. She has no history of recent injury. Her active and passive ranges of motion are quite limited on abduction, external rotation, and internal rotation. She has a mildly positive impingement sign with normal strength. An x-ray of the right shoulder shows no abnormalities. Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Glenohumeral osteoarthritis can limit internal rotation of the shoulder but is typically associated with radiographic abnormalities.

B) INCORRECT:

Glenohumeral dislocation can limit internal rotation of the shoulder but is typically associated with radiographic abnormalities.

C) INCORRECT:

Supraspinatus tears are associated with limited abduction but not limited internal rotation; they are also associated with weakness with active abduction, particularly when the arm is hanging in the neutral position.

D) INCORRECT:

Bicipital tendinosis is not usually associated with substantially limited range of motion.

E) CORRECT:

Adhesive capsulitis typically develops subacutely. It manifests as pain and limited range of motion on abduction, internal rotation, and external rotation. Without antecedent trauma, adhesive capsulitis is much more common in patients with diabetes mellitus than in nondiabetic patients. Therapeutic interventions for adhesive capsulitis include physical therapy, intra-articular glucocorticoid injection, and (for refractory cases) arthroscopic surgical release and/or manipulation under anesthesia.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in a patient with limited passive and active range of motion in abduction, internal rotation, and external rotation of the shoulder is adhesive capsulitis.
questions.hint: In addition to diabetes mellitus, patients with thyroid disorders and scleroderma are also at increased risk of developing this condition.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man reports severe pain in his left shoulder for several days. He did not fall or injure his shoulder. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows tenderness of the greater tuberosity of the left humerus. There is no swelling or erythema. The patient is unable to slowly adduct the left arm after it is passively abducted to 90 degrees, and external rotation is limited by pain. Subacromial injection of lidocaine does not relieve his symptoms. An x-ray of the left shoulder shows sclerosis of the acromion and humeral head. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Reassurance and referral for physical therapy

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Simple shoulder slings are used for the conservative management of nondisplaced clavicular fractures in which there is no neurovascular compromise. This patient has no history of a recent fall or trauma and no evidence of clavicular fracture on physical examination (e.g., foreshortening of the shoulder girdle, elevation of the acromioclavicular joint), or shoulder x-ray.

B) CORRECT:

Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is the preferred modality for assessing rotator cuff tears. T1-weighted images can show discontinuity of the tendon and loss of the subacromial fat plane, and T2-weighted images can show fluid in the subacromial space. MRIs are also helpful for evaluating whether the tear is amenable to surgical management and for planning such an operation. This patient likely has a chronic degenerative rotator cuff tear, which typically manifests in older adults (> 50 years) with no history of trauma. Acute rotator cuff tears generally occur secondary to trauma (e.g., fall on an outstretched arm).

Musculoskeletal ultrasonography (MSUS) is a cost-effective alternative to traditional MRI for rotator cuff tear evaluation. MSUS allows for detailed visualization of specific shoulder regions at rest and during movement. Typical ultrasonographic findings of rotator cuff tear include focal hypoechoic and/or anechoic areas with evidence of fiber discontinuity juxtaposed with the hyperechoic fibrillar pattern of the undamaged tendon.
Image Description:

The top image shows a cross-section of the shoulder joint.

The bottom images show the progression of a degenerative rotator cuff tear. Repetitive overhead movement and/or anatomical variants of the acromion can result in inflammation of the subacromial bursa and rotator cuff tendons (left). This may progress to degeneration of the bursa and tendons (middle). As a result, the tendon fibers are less elastic and prone to tear, resulting in a rotator cuff tear (right). The supraspinatus tendon is most commonly affected.

C) INCORRECT:

Surgical fixation (e.g., arthroscopic or open rotator cuff repair) is recommended for acute traumatic rupture, especially in younger patients, athletes, and patients in which conservative treatment does not provide pain and functional relief. Surgery is not recommended for degenerative rupture in elderly and/or inactive individuals like this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Arthrocentesis of the shoulder is indicated when a synovial fluid analysis is required to rule out pathologies such as joint infection (septic arthritis) or crystal-induced arthropathy (e.g., gout, pseudogout). This patient has no history of trauma during which bacteria could possibly have been introduced into the shoulder. In addition, he lacks symptoms of local inflammation (e.g., joint swelling, erythema) and fever, making infection and crystal-induced arthropathy unlikely.

E) INCORRECT:

Reassurance is indicated in patients with simple muscle strains. This patient with a suspected rotator cuff tear on examination requires further investigation to confirm the diagnosis followed by management, which could include avoidance of activities involving overhead movements, NSAIDs, and physical therapy.
questions.hint: Shoulder pain, tenderness of the greater tuberosity, a positive drop arm test, limitation of external rotation, and a negative lidocaine injection test raise suspicion for a rotator cuff tear.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman with type 1 diabetes mellitus comes to your clinic with a 3-month history of worsening right shoulder pain. She reports difficulty reaching overhead and behind her back. There is no history of recent injury. Both active and passive ranges of motion are significantly limited in abduction, external rotation, and internal rotation. She has a mildly positive impingement sign, and her strength is normal. An x-ray of the right shoulder is normal. Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Glenohumeral dislocation can limit internal rotation of the shoulder but is typically associated with radiographic abnormalities.

B) INCORRECT:

Glenohumeral osteoarthritis can limit internal rotation of the shoulder but is typically associated with radiographic abnormalities.

C) CORRECT:

Adhesive capsulitis typically develops subacutely. It manifests as pain and limited range of motion on abduction, internal rotation, and external rotation. Without antecedent trauma, adhesive capsulitis is much more common in patients with diabetes mellitus than in nondiabetic patients. Therapeutic interventions for adhesive capsulitis include physical therapy, intra-articular glucocorticoid injection, and (for refractory cases) arthroscopic surgical release and/or manipulation under anesthesia.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in a patient with limited passive and active range of motion in abduction, internal rotation, and external rotation of the shoulder is adhesive capsulitis.

D) INCORRECT:

Bicipital tendinosis is not usually associated with substantially limited range of motion.

E) INCORRECT:

Supraspinatus tears are associated with limited abduction but not limited internal rotation; they are also associated with weakness with active abduction, particularly when the arm is hanging in the neutral position.
questions.hint: In addition to diabetes mellitus, patients with thyroid disorders and scleroderma are also at increased risk of developing this condition.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to your clinic with severe pain in his left shoulder that has persisted for several days. He denies any trauma or injury. Vital signs are normal. On examination, there is tenderness over the greater tuberosity of the left humerus without swelling or erythema. He is unable to slowly adduct his left arm after passive abduction to 90 degrees, and external rotation is limited by pain. Subacromial injection of lidocaine does not relieve his symptoms. An x-ray of the left shoulder shows sclerosis of the acromion and humeral head. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Reassurance and referral for physical therapy.

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is the preferred modality for assessing rotator cuff tears. T1-weighted images can show discontinuity of the tendon and loss of the subacromial fat plane, and T2-weighted images can show fluid in the subacromial space. MRIs are also helpful for evaluating whether the tear is amenable to surgical management and for planning such an operation. This patient likely has a chronic degenerative rotator cuff tear, which typically manifests in older adults (> 50 years) with no history of trauma. Acute rotator cuff tears generally occur secondary to trauma (e.g., fall on an outstretched arm).

Musculoskeletal ultrasonography (MSUS) is a cost-effective alternative to traditional MRI for rotator cuff tear evaluation. MSUS allows for detailed visualization of specific shoulder regions at rest and during movement. Typical ultrasonographic findings of rotator cuff tear include focal hypoechoic and/or anechoic areas with evidence of fiber discontinuity juxtaposed with the hyperechoic fibrillar pattern of the undamaged tendon.

Key learning point: Magnetic resonance imaging is the preferred modality for diagnosing rotator cuff tears, providing detailed assessment of tendon integrity and guiding management decisions.
Image Description:

The top image shows a cross-section of the shoulder joint.

The bottom images show the progression of a degenerative rotator cuff tear. Repetitive overhead movement and/or anatomical variants of the acromion can result in inflammation of the subacromial bursa and rotator cuff tendons (left). This may progress to degeneration of the bursa and tendons (middle). As a result, the tendon fibers are less elastic and prone to tear, resulting in a rotator cuff tear (right). The supraspinatus tendon is most commonly affected.

B) INCORRECT:

Simple shoulder slings are used for the conservative management of nondisplaced clavicular fractures in which there is no neurovascular compromise. This patient has no history of a recent fall or trauma and no evidence of clavicular fracture on physical examination (e.g., foreshortening of the shoulder girdle, elevation of the acromioclavicular joint), or shoulder x-ray.

C) INCORRECT:

Reassurance is indicated in patients with simple muscle strains. This patient with a suspected rotator cuff tear on examination requires further investigation to confirm the diagnosis followed by management, which could include avoidance of activities involving overhead movements, NSAIDs, and physical therapy.

D) INCORRECT:

Arthrocentesis of the shoulder is indicated when a synovial fluid analysis is required to rule out pathologies such as joint infection (septic arthritis) or crystal-induced arthropathy (e.g., gout, pseudogout). This patient has no history of trauma during which bacteria could possibly have been introduced into the shoulder. In addition, he lacks symptoms of local inflammation (e.g., joint swelling, erythema) and fever, making infection and crystal-induced arthropathy unlikely.

E) INCORRECT:

Surgical fixation (e.g., arthroscopic or open rotator cuff repair) is recommended for acute traumatic rupture, especially in younger patients, athletes, and patients in which conservative treatment does not provide pain and functional relief. Surgery is not recommended for degenerative rupture in elderly and/or inactive individuals like this patient.
questions.hint: Shoulder pain, tenderness of the greater tuberosity, a positive drop arm test, limitation of external rotation, and a negative lidocaine injection test raise suspicion for a rotator cuff tear.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man who works as a painter presents with a 2-week history of progressive right shoulder pain and weakness. He reports difficulty reaching overhead and lifting paint cans. Physical examination shows subacromial tenderness and weakness with shoulder abduction. Range of motion testing shows restricted active abduction but normal passive range of motion. A painful arc is noted between 60120 degrees of abduction. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Obtain plain radiographs of the shoulder

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intra-articular corticosteroid injection may be considered for rotator cuff tendinopathy, but only after initial imaging has been obtained to rule out other pathology. Additionally, the presence of weakness with restricted active range of motion suggests possible rotator cuff tear, which has different management considerations than simple tendinopathy.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- Plain radiographs are the initial imaging study for all patients with shoulder pain to rule out fractures, dislocations, and other bony abnormalities. This patient's clinical presentation suggests rotator cuff pathology, but imaging is required to exclude other causes before proceeding with further management. X-rays may also show calcific deposits or degenerative changes that could influence treatment decisions.

C) INCORRECT:

MRI is the gold standard for evaluating rotator cuff pathology but is typically reserved for when conservative management is unsuccessful or surgical intervention is being considered. Plain radiographs should be obtained to rule out other causes of shoulder pain before proceeding to advanced imaging.

D) INCORRECT:

The combination of weakness and restricted active range of motion with normal passive range suggests a possible rotator cuff tear. Physical therapy is an important component of conservative management for rotator cuff disease but should not be initiated until imaging has been obtained to rule out a bony injury that could be worsened by physical therapy.

E) INCORRECT:

NSAIDs and activity modification are appropriate conservative measures for rotator cuff tendinopathy, but this patient's clinical presentation with weakness and restricted active range of motion suggests a possible rotator cuff tear, and bony injury must be ruled out before implementing conservative management strategies.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman who is a construction worker presents with 8 weeks of progressive shoulder pain after a fall while working. The pain is worse at night and with overhead activities. Examination shows subacromial tenderness and positive empty can test. Active shoulder abduction is limited to 90 degrees, but passive range of motion is full. Drop arm test is negative. The patient reports she needs to return to work soon and asks about her options. What is the most appropriate next step?

choices.text: Conservative management with activity modification and NSAIDs
MRI to rule out rotator cuff tear

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Shoulder immobilization is unadvisable in rotator cuff tendinopathy because immobilization can lead to adhesive capsulitis. Active movement within the pain-free range is encouraged, and immobilization is only used for comfort in acute full-thickness tears.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- Conservative management is the most appropriate initial approach for rotator cuff tendinopathy. This patient's clinical findings suggest tendinopathy rather than full-thickness tear, making conservative therapy with activity modification, NSAIDs, and eventual physical therapy the standard first-line treatment.

C) INCORRECT:

Subacromial corticosteroid injection is considered for refractory chronic pain after initial conservative measures have been unsuccessful. First-line options should be tried first.

D) INCORRECT:

MRI is not routinely required for initial management of clinically diagnosed rotator cuff tendinopathy. Imaging is typically obtained when symptoms persist after conservative treatment or when there is diagnostic uncertainty about the extent of injury.

E) INCORRECT:

Urgent orthopedic surgery referral is not indicated for rotator cuff tendinopathy without evidence of full-thickness tear. The negative drop arm test and preserved passive range of motion suggest intact rotator cuff function.
